Also, Angela Merkel is due to speak in the Bundestag before the Summit - any time now....

Updated at 12.18pm BST

7.53am BST

EU SUMMIT BEGINS IN BRUSSELS TODAY

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the eurozone financial crisis, and other key events in the global economy.

It's a big day, as European leaders gather in Brussels for the eagerly awaited EU Summit.

The meeting will see heated debate on issues such as banking union and eurozone budgets. Spain's possible bailout and the Greek aid package also likely to dominate the chat in the corridors of power.

We're not expecting a major breakthrough (but we'd love to be disappointed). Instead, there's likely to be a major tussle between Angela Merkel and François Hollande, with the French president expected to challenge Germany's chancellor over Berlin's hard line on austerity and foot-dragging over European banking supervision.

Meanwhile, over in Greece workers will be taking part in a general strike in protest at the country's financial plight. Unions will be holding demonstrations in Athens, in the latest sign of public anger over the worsening situation in Greece.

We'll be tracking all the action in Brussels and Athens through the day. (full agenda to follow).
fields.bodyText: We're closing this live blog now but coverage will continue tomorrow. We'll leave you with the latest Reuters report from Brussels: Direct recapitalisation of troubled banks by the European Stability Mechanism bailout fund could be a reality for some lenders at the end of the first quarter of 2013, a French government source said on Thursday. The source, briefed on talks between European Union leaders in Brussels, said a deal had been reached at the summit on having a legal framework for a banking union by the end of 2012, with the aim of putting 6,000 European banks under direct supervision of the European Central Bank by early 2014. The source also said Germany was ready to discuss the possibility of transferring under the umbrella of the ESM legacy assets from banks currently under state aid or being recapitalised before the single supervision system is in place. The source said one solution for dealing with legacy assets of banks could be to split the burden between the states and the ESM bailout fund, under conditions yet to be defined by finance ministers. Good night and thanks for reading. Well now it looks like predictions that the end is in sight were a little premature, according to Reuters' correspondent at the summit: Current estimates range from 30 minutes to an hour. So don't hold your breath. Just to add to the night's cheer, credit rating agency Moody's says the outlook for German banks remains negative. Well this summit has now gone on more than two hour longer than (perhaps optimistically) predicted. But there are signs the end is in sight, according to journalists in attendance: My colleague David Batty suggests the EU needs to introduce chess match style time control to make decisions. That seems appropriate as Hollande has been playing the French defence against Merkel, and seemingly losing. Peter Spiegel, Brussels bureau chief of the Financial Times, notes on Twitter that the Germans are not disputing French officials' assertion that the new European Central Bank supervision will start in January and be phased in over a year. "Sounds darn close 2 Commission proposal," he adds. Although the new Eurozone banking supervisor's remit won't stretch to Britain, UK banks could be affected – if they have operations in the EMU region or have subsidiaries there. Twitter user 'A Libetarian Rebel' reckons we must check the details closely (assuming they are *ever* agreed): The worst-case scenario for David Cameron would be a supervisory structure that wasn't robust enough to really improve the Eurozone, but which was intrusive enough to hit the City. Marco Zatterin, the Brussels correspondent of the Italian newspaper La Stampa, suggests that the Germans have a different interpretation of the deal. In fact, our unnamed French official is helpfully giving a lot of detail about the banking supervision plans being hammered out at the Summit. Here's the snaps, via the Reuters terminal: • FRENCH GOVT SOURCE: DEAL REACHED AT EU SUMMIT ON HAVING LEGAL FRAMEWORK FOR BANKING UNION BY END 2012, COMPLETION BY EARLY 2014 • FRENCH GOVT SOURCE: GERMANY HAS AGREED FOR 6,000 BANKS TO BE UNDER UNIQUE SUPERVISION OF ECB, DAY-TO-DAY SUPERVISION COULD BE DELEGATED TO NATIONAL SUPERVISORS •FRENCH GOVT SOURCE: ECB TO START SUPERVISING BANKS UNDER STATE AID FIRST • FRENCH GOVT SOURCE: DIRECT RECAPITALISATION OF BANKS TO BE A REALITY IN 2013, LIKELY IN FIRST QUARTER FOR SOME BANKS • FRENCH GOVT SOURCE: ISSUES OF LEGACY ASSETS FOR BANKS ALREADY UNDER STATE AID TO BE DISCUSSED BY DECEMBER, GERMANY NOT OPPOSED IN PRINCIPLE • FRENCH GOVT SOURCE: ONE POSSIBILITY WOULD BE TO SHARE BANKS' LEGACY ASSETS BETWEEN STATES AND EURO ZONE RESCUE FUNDS So we might not need the press conference at all! #zzzz French government officials are taking the chance to brief euro hacks about how the new banking supervisor might work: Further confirmation that the EU summit is dragging on.... And the talks between EU leaders continue to drag on.... the very latest word from Brussels is that negotiations may last another hour (!) Reuters are now billing the changes on setting up a single European banking supervisor as a "compromise' between Berlin and Paris: European Union leaders struck a compromise on a roadmap to establish a single bank supervisor for the euro zone after Germany and France papered over differences on priorities for overcoming the bloc's debt crisis. Diplomats reading from the text of draft conclusions of an EU summit in Brussels on Thursday said the leaders agreed on "the objective of completing the legal framework by the end of the year" with implementation "in the course of 2013". So, being optimistic, at least leaders did still agree to set up a single supervisor for eurozone banks. In a nutshell, all European leaders have agreed so far tonight is to make a tiny (backwards) change to the existing plan on banking supervision. Specifically, from "with the aim of completing banking union legislation" by the end of this year, to "with the aim of agreeing banking union legislation". The press pack is not impressed: The word from Brussels tonight is that a press conference is still expected at some point. However, insiders say that the leaders are only on the 12th point on their agenda, out of 21..... EU spokesman Olivier Bailly has presented the decision on banking supervision as a positive step, even though leaders appear to have rowed back on their deadline plans: Dow Jones Newswires has also weighed in, agreeing that the Eurozone leaders appear to have given up on the idea of getting banking supervision formally agreed by the end of this year: Megan Greene of Roubini also isn't impressed that Eu leaders have merely agreed to complete the legal work on the SIngle Supervisory Mechanism for European banking by the end of the year (see 9.20pm onwards). Jonathan Faull, director general of the European Commission, has hailed the news that EU leaders have agreed to finalise the legal framework of the the banking supervision system by the end of 2012: Faull tweeted: But as I blogged at 21.20, this is not the same as implementing banking supervision by the end of the year. Which is what many people though was agreed back in June. The FT's Peter Spiegel makes the same point: Here's the Press Association's take of what David Cameron has been up to in Brussels: Prime Minister David Cameron was tonight urging swift moves towards a banking union for the eurozone - without compromising the EU single currency. He told fellow EU leaders at a summit in Brussels that Britain backed the plan, including sweeping supervision not just for the biggest banks but smaller institutions too. And over dinner later he was setting out the need not just for a single supervisor to govern the eurozone, but for a comprehensive system of resolution funds - to cover the wind-up of failing banks - and deposit guarantees to restore stability and credibility. You know things are quiet in Brussels when members of the elite press pack have time to pose for photos.... Associated Press is also reporting that EU leaders have agreed to finish the legal work creating a single eurozone banking supervisor, and that the plan will be implemented during 2013 (as mentioned at 9.20pm) AP says: German diplomats say leaders meeting in Brussels have reached agreement on creating a powerful single supervisor for eurozone banks and the plan will be implemented at some point next year. France and Germany have been tussling over how to best shore up Europe's struggling banks. France wanted a single supervisor in place by the end of this year because that would allow Europe's bailout fund to directly loan money to banks, a key tool in fighting the crisis. But Germany has been dragging its heels because it's nervous about such loans. The diplomats said leaders reached agreement Thursday night to draw up the legal basis for the supervisor by the end of this year. They will then put it into place sometime in 2013. Our Europe editor Ian Traynor reports that France and Germany are locked in "their worst showdown" since the three-year euro crisis began. Ian says there was little sign of progress at the meeting between François Hollande and Angela Merkel, writing: They were seen walking together grim-faced into the summit room, with Hollande speaking to Merkel and the chancellor appearing to say 'no' three times. Nein, Nein, Nein? Sums things up, really. Ian adds that Hollande "flatly dismissed" German demands for a new European "budgets tsar" who would be able to overrule national governments and parliaments on tax-and-spend policies in the eurozone. Here's Hollande's key quotes: The topic of this summit is not the fiscal union but the banking union, so the only decision that will be taken is to set up a banking union by the end of the year and especially the banking supervision,... Merkel has her own deadline, in September 2013," he added caustically, referring to next year's general election in which the German leader is seeking a third term. A development on the push for eurozone banking supervision, via the Reuters team in Brussels: European Union leaders agreed on Thursday to complete the legal work on setting up a single bank supervisor for financial institutions in the euro zone by the end of the year and that the implementation of the plan would be gradual over 2013. EU diplomats, reading from the text of draft conclusions of the summit in Brussels, said the leaders agreed on "the objective of completing of the legal frame work by the end of the year" with implementation "in the course of 2013". Hmmm. "Complete the legal work" sounds rather less concrete than "set up", and "gradual implementation...in the course of 2013" is not the rapid decision that France et al were after. It's not the final conclusions, of course, but it suggests Angela Merkel didn't make a concession today. This is interesting - European leaders have apparently been considering the knotty problem of who should pick up the Nobel Peace Prize in December. The idea of sending a group of young people to Oslo is, apparently, gathering some support. It worked rather well for the London Olympics, after all. David Cameron has backed the idea, according to Luke Baker of Reuters. Although (and this isn't really in the spirit of peace), there's disagreement over who came up with the idea first: Another line out of Brussels: Angela Merkel is going to hold talks with Greece's Antonis Samaras on Friday morning. Fund manager @pawelmorski believes the rumour that the eurozone might buy more of Greece's debt (see previous post) will spark a rally in Greek bonds in the morning. News out of Brussels in the last few minutes - the Wall Street Journal reports that eurozone leaders have been considering a proposal that they buy Greek debt in the bond markets, and then 'retire' some of it. This would cut Athens' debt burden. However... Megan Greene, eurozone crisis at Roubini, reckons the plan would not work. She argued earlier this week that such a proposal could be counter-productive, as it would drive bond prices up: This will not only render the operation extremely expensive and inefficient, but it could incentivize banks to hold onto their peripheral sovereign debt; if bond prices are rising, then the value that banks can borrow against that collateral will improve. Meg's full argument is here. Another photo just arrived, showing Italian prime minister Mario Monti and French president François Hollande walking'n'talking after a bilateral meeting on the sidelines of the EU summit. Reuters reported earlier that Monti and Hollande discussed the situation in Spain and Italy - which might explain the pained look on the Italian leader's face. Finland's Europe's minister has suggested that Britain is making a deliberate effort to alienate itself from the rest of the EU at today's summit. Alex Stubb said it feels like the UK is saying 'bye bye' to the other members of the 27-strong community, at a time when closer integration is on the cards. Reuters has the story. Here's the key quotes: It's almost as if it's 26 plus 1, to be very honest.... I think Britain is right now, voluntarily, by its own will, putting itself in the margins. Stubb's comments come a few days after the UK government announced plans to attempt to repatriate powers from the EU. This move has not been warmly welcomed by the rest of the EU, who are more concerned with holding the Union together. Stubbs added: It's almost as if the boat is pulling away and one of our best friends is somehow saying 'bye bye' and there's not really that much we can do about it. David Cameron certainly didn't make an effort to be at the centre of today's family photo.... Give up? He's on the back row, one from the end on the right hand side. Neatly obscured by Mark Rutte. Cameron spoke to journalists on his way into the summit a few hours ago, and said his plan was to push very hard for the European single market to be completed. Calling it Europe's biggest asset, Cameron said it was wrong that it did not yet stretch to cover services, digital and energy. I"m sure you're wondering what the EU leaders are having for dinner: Well, Yann Ollivier of AFP has the answer: No mention of wine. Perhaps that's where they're going wrong. While EU leaders get stuck into dinner and those big decisions, let's mop up a few eurozone stories that got neglected earlier today 1) Italy has conducted a huge debt sale. The Italian treasury has pulled €18bn into its coffers, though a highly successful auction of a four-year inflation-linked bond. The FT reports that this is Italy's biggest single debt sale ever - and a sign of growing confidence in the country. 2) Signs of life in the Spanish economy New data showed a 3.8% jump in Spanish industrial output in August, and a 1% rise in new orders. Economist Shaun Richards was heartened by the data, and suggested that it could help push Spanish borrowing costs down. Spain's 10-year bond yields fell again today, finishing at 5.3% -- the lowest since April. Over in Brussels leaders are now sitting down for a working dinner. The original timings have been knocked off by Angela Merkel and Francois Hollande's unexpected meeting a couple of hours ago. According to the original agenda, the working dinner was due to last from 8pm till 10pm Brussels time, followed by a press conference. If that remains the plan, I'd guess we'll get a press conference around 9pm BST. Here's another snap from the EU Family Photo. I'm sure you don't need me to tell you that the top row (from left) are Belgium's prime minister Elio Di Rupo, Spain's prime minister Mariano Rajoy, and Sweden's prime minister Fredrik Reinfeld. Below (from left) it's Ireland's prime minister Enda Kenny, European Parliament president Martin Schulz and Romania's president Traian Basescu. The EU leaders just held their traditional family photo - and they didn't exactly hang around. Thus the hastily grabbed image above... The meeting between Angela Merkel and Francois Hollande has ended, and the two sides are now briefing selected journalists. The German side are saying the talks were pleasant, but it's not clear whether much was agreed. That's via my former, distinguished colleague David Gow who now works for the Nucleus campaign group. Meanwhile a French source has told Reuters that a provisional deal on banking union COULD be reached today. Here are the newswire snaps: • FRENCH GOVT SOURCE: HOLLANDE AND MERKEL AGREED ON NEED FOR TIGHT, CLEAR TIMEFRAME ON BANKING UNION • FRENCH GOVT SOURCE: DECISION IN PRINCIPLE ON BANKING UNION LIKELY T O BE REACHED AT THURSDAY SUMMIT, BUT FURTHER DETAILS TO BE DISCUSSED LATER THIS YEAR • FRENCH GOVT SOURCE: HOLLANDE DISCUSSED WITH ITALY'S MONTI AND WITH GERMANY'S MERKEL THE SITUATION IN GREECE AND SPAIN I'd suggest that any deal on banking union would be very provisional -- Brussels officials had already guided that the issue would be kicked across to the finance ministers to resolve at their own meeting next month. EU insiders are dampening expectations that the eurozone leaders might take themselves away for a special meeting tonight, according to Luke Baker of Reuters: This is the first photo we've received from inside the summit. Ireland's Prime Minister Enda Kenny (left) is shown chatting with Lithuania's President Dalia Grybauskaite (centre) and Germany's Chancellor Angela Merkel. Sony Kapoor of the ReDefine think tank (and one of the most clued-up commentators on the crisis), argues that Francois Hollande is quite right to push back against Germany (as explained at 16.37) He also isn't expecting much progress this week: JUST IN: the leaders of Germany and France are holding an unscheduled meeting right now. The move is an attempt to iron out some of their disagreements before getting down to business with the other 25 leaders from across the EU. Ian Traynor reports from Brussels: Merkel and Hollande, the twin poles of conflict at this summit, are meeting before the full session gets under way. Hollande wants to focus on banking union and supervision, getting the thing up and running as fast as possible. Merkel wants to turn attention to more fiscal discipline and Europeanised control of eurozone budgets. Hollande said this was the wrong time to open discussion on a budget pact. Reaching agreement before the Summit gets fully underway could be a challenge -- indeed, one worthy of the Nobel Peace Prize..... ..speaking of which, Herman Van Rompuy has just announced that he wants every EU leader to collect the Prize in December: Austrian chancellor Werner Faymann struck a conciliatory tone as he arrived for the Summit a little while ago. He declared that the EU should "show solidarity" to Greece, Spain and Cyprus. Mariano Rajoy, Enda Kenny and Antonis Samaras (the leaders of Spain, Ireland and Greece) all slipped in without speaking to the press. Was it something we said? From Brussels, our Europe editor Ian Traynor reports that officials and diplomats are predicting a bit of a bruiser: Ian writes: Paris and Berlin presenting conflicting demands that boil down to a power grab by Berlin for control of other people's budgets and a bid by Paris to force Germany to shell out more quickly and more easily for bailouts and shoring up dodgy banks. Neither side is likely to win, at least not tonight or tomorrow. Brinkmanship, maximalist agendas, to be resolved needless to say at some stage in a euro-fudge. When that might be is anyone's guess, perhaps in December when Herman Van Rompuy, chairing the summits, unveils his "roadmap" for "completing" the single currency's monetary union, a work in progress. Last night leaders were to "explore" Van Rompuy's initial ideas and doubtless scrap over them. They revolve around establishing a modest eurozone "budget" to be spent on mitigating the impact of structural reforms that eurozone governments sign up to via "contracts" with the European Commission. Mariano Rajoy of Spain is extremely unlikely to ask for a bailout just days before elections in his native region of Galicia. The Greek dilemmas, while being discussed in the corridors and in the many bilateral meetings taking place on the fringes of the summit, have been shelved until next month and handed over to eurozone finance ministers to sort out. So when Angela Merkel declared a few minutes ago that nothing would be agreed, she wasn't joking.... Two developments of interest in Athens 1) The BBC's Mark Lowen reports that the man who died during the protests today had collapsed before the riot police began using teargas. 2) A Greek politician has downplayed the turnout of today's protests, to the chagrin of those on the streets. Adonis Georgiadi of New Democracy claimed that the PAME union did not manage a great turnout (despite appearing to fill Syntagma Square pretty effectively - see 10.58BST) Angela Merkel has arrived for the Brussels summit, and poured cold water over hopes of a major breakthrough over the next two days. Merkel told reporters jostling outside the Justus Lipsius building that it was important to move quickly, but to also be "thorough". The German chancellor then added: No major decisions are likely at the summit That may be an attempt to lower expectations, ready for a surprise. Or it maybe simply be further proof that Berlin and Paris are going to clash over banking union and fiscal union, to little reward. The Brussels news machine is whirling away as the Summit kicks into action. Europa's Cerstin Gammelin reports that Angela Merkel and François Hollande may hold one-on-one talks in an attempt to smooth out the disagreements between France and Germany. While James Kanter of the International Herald Tribune and the New York Times says that the 17 members of the eurozone could break away from the 10 "outs" and hold their own private talks late tonight. Back to Brussels, and here are a few photos of leaders arriving for the Summit: It appears that the man who very sadly suffered a heart attack and died during the Athens protests was 65. Associated Press reports: A 65-year-old protester suffered a fatal heart attack during the demonstration but efforts to revive him failed. The organizers of the protest march he participated in said the man had fallen ill before any rioting had broken out. Back to Greece. Unionists have told Helena Smith that the turn-out for today's demonstrations was much bigger than the mass rallies held last week to protest a visit to Athens by German chancellor Angela Merkel. Tania Karayiannis at ADEDY, the civil servants' union, told Helena: In Athens the turn-out was huge. We estimate that there were well over 80,000. People weren't afraid this time to come down town which they were when the police turned out in force for Merkel. In Greece's northern capital, Thessaloniki, about 15,000 took to the streets, Karayiannis said, adding: Greeks are becoming increasingly conscious of what is happening and it was especially noticeable that the main slogan today was 'the time has come to overthrow these policies," The political leadership of this country should not under-estimate that. If they don't take our opposition seriously they will bear historic responsibility for the disintegration of Greece's social fabric and the developments that will surely follow. Greece may have its peculiarities, there may be things that have to change but clearly this is not only a Greek problem. It is a European problem that has to be solved at a central European level and the way to do that is not to keep chipping away at wages and causing joblessness and poverty. Austerity is not the way out. And here's one more photo from the protests earlier today: EU leaders and officials have begun arriving in Brussels for his afternoon's summit (which concludes tomorrow), and the European press pack in Brussels are assembled to catch their words of wisdom It looks quite lively. Indeed, Matina Stevis of the Wall Street Journal reckons it's the busiest she can remember: That looks like Mark Rutte, prime minister of the Netherlands, to me. He told reporters that Greece 'probably won't be on the agenda' today. That fits with earlier reports that Antonis Samaras, Greek PM, will give a statement on the situation. There have been important developments in Brussels already today, while we've been focusing on Athens. European Commission president José Manuel Barroso has rebuked EU leaders for not doing more to develop growth across the EU, following this morning's Tripartite Social Summit. Barroso told reporters that he was unhappy with progress so far, and demanded a new sense of urgency. He also signalled to Berlin to allow austerity to be relaxed. Easier said than done. The full statement is online here. Here's the key section: Very frankly I am not happy with the progress made so far. That's why I call on the European Council to accelerate the adoption and implementation of many important growth-enhancing measures included in the Growth and Jobs Compact. It is true that we have been making more efforts in terms of fiscal consolidation than on the measures for growth that were already agreed at the European Council level. We need to balance the important efforts made in terms of sound public finances with the right measures to have growth enhancing policies. We also need to move ahead with our structural reform agenda – the country-specific recommendations have to be implemented at national level. Greek police have confirmed that a man has died during today's protests (as reported at 13.40) Greece's police spokesman Lieutenant Colonel Christos Manouras says the dead man's body has been taken to Athens' biggest public hospital, Evangelismos. An autopsy will take place shortly. "There is some speculation that he had a fainting fit and other suggestions that he either suffered a cardiac arrest or stroke," Manouras told Helena Smith, our Athens correspondent. Manouras added: We will only know once the coroner has conducted an autopsy, but what I can say is that there were no police or skirmishes at the spot at which he died. In other words, the death was not provoked by violence. News of the death has cast a dark cloud over Greece. This is the fifth person to die during Athens protests since 2010 -- following the man who died of a heart attack a year ago, and the three people who died in May 2010 when a bank building caught fire. There is anger on the streets of Athens that the riot police are using tear gas -- although at this stage we do not know the precise causes of the death today. Helena confirms that "there was a lot of tear gas today - and quite unwarranted too". She adds: Greek police, meanwhile, are refusing to say how many turned out for today's demonstrations and will release figures in the next hour or so. Unions are calling it "one of the biggest protests" so far but again have yet to release figures. Here's our first video clip from Athens, showing how today's general strike has brought parts of Greece to a standstill. It also include interviews with Athenians, explaining their concerns over the country's financial crisis. From the streets of Athens, Helena Smith reports that rows of helmeted riot police are blocking access to Syntagma square from what appears to be every street. In years of covering streets demos in Athens she's have never seen this before - so "obviously a new police tactic". Helena adds: Protestors gathered at Ermou have become so frustrated they have been yelling "you have shit under your helmets" at police. More than one told me that the new tactic -- "this police terrorism" -- represents mounting fears that the parliament building, itself, could soon be stormed. "People either don't have work or they they are becoming policemen because the police force is the only body that is hiring and pays relatively well," said 33-year-old computer scientist Thassos Kontogiorgis. "Ever more of the new recruits are going straight into the riot police. And basically they are thugs." Kontogiorgos, who returned from studying in California a year ago in the hope of finding a job, says in December he will join the growing numbers of young Greeks migrating abroad. "Me and four of my friends, all computer scientists, are about to go to Canada. We belong to a lost generation. We can't be creative here. Our country can give us nothing," said the long-haired youth thronged by protestors screaming abuse at the police. Greek Television station Skai TV is reporting that one person has died during today's protests in Athens. The 67-year-old man is said to have died of a heart attack. Very sad if true. It's very reminiscent of a similar death almost a year ago, when a "middle-aged trade unionist" collapsed and died during a protest (details) Reuters reckons that more than 30,000 people took part in today's demonstrations in Athens, and that the trouble began when "a small group of protesters" began throwing marble, bottles and petrol bombs at the ropt police who were "barricading part of the square". It appears that the Greek riot police have managed to clear Syntagma Square of most protesters: Our correspondent in Athens, Helena Smith, reports that the situation at Syntagma Square is now "very tense". She says: I am standing on Mitropoleos opposite the old education ministry where riot police have blocked off access to the square. There are lots of very angry young demonstrators - many holding rocks. There are loud blasts of stun guns echoing around, and police helicopers are flying overhead. Helena has also been hearing heart-wrenching stories of hardship on the streets. And protestors are also complaining that despite being peaceful demonstration, riot police are deliberately emptying Syntagma square. 59-year-old geologist Nora Hayiou told Helena: Its a totally peaceful march and less than half those participating have actually got to the square and already they have started firing teargas.... It seems as though we are not even allowed to demonstrate any more. And here are two photos that show the two different sides of today's demonstrations - the peaceful, and the violent: As a reminder, here's three places to watch live TV from Athens: • Zougra • Russia Today • Syntagma-live.blogspot.fr Looking at another live feed from Syntagma, it appears that police have formed lines at various points of the Square, but that peaceful protesters are still there in number: The police may be preparing to clear the square: This photo from Syntagma Square shows "Junta HQ" sprayed on the steps of the Parliament building, alongside a man selling gas masks (with thanks to Asteris Masouras , who is also tweeting from the scene). Theodora Oikonomides reports from Syntagma Square that four protestors have been taken away by ambulance, and that one of them was "rather seriously" hurt. Here's a pic of one of the wounded: According to local reports, there were riot police on every Athens street corner, with around 4,000 officers deployed. That's at least two thousand fewer than were needed to guard Angela Merkel - which makes sense, as they also had to protect the German chancellor as she travelled to and from the airport on her visit last week. Incidentally, Reuters has a quote from utility worker Konstantinos Balomenos which shows the depth of despair in Greece now: Enough is enough. They've dug our graves, shoved us in and we are waiting for the priest to read the last words," said Konstantinos Balomenos, a 58-year-old worker at a water utility whose wage has been halved to 900 euros and has two unemployed sons. This austerity is making all of Europe's south rebel, the euro will be destroyed. We are asked to pay for what our politicians have embezzled. Here's a better photo showing the moment that the Athens general strike turned violent, when a petrol bomb cocktail landed close to the riot police in Syntagma Square (as I blogged at 11.46am) And above is an image of a protestor (with his face largely concealed) kicking a riot police shield. As usual, the vast majority of the people taking part in the demo are behaving peacefully. The live video feed shows that marching groups have continued to arrive at one end of Syntagma, even after people at the other end were driven away. One of those groups includes the youth section of the left-wing Syriza party, who carried a banner reading "revolt is our duty" (hat-tip to Spyros again) It appears that many people are being forced out of Syntagma Square now. Spyros Gkelis reports from the scene that people are struggling to breath after teargas was deployed by riot police, and tweets from the scene: And here's another photo from this web feed, taken a few minutes ago. Just watched a small number of individuals throwing objects at the riot police in Syntagma, who didn't appear to respond. After perhaps a minute, the group dispersed and a large group of peaceful demonstrators marched through. Here's another image from the scene: That comes from this webfeed from Syntagma. Right now, the scene appears peaceful again.... Just seen the first motolov cocktail thrown in Athens -- here's a photo of it lying smoking on the ground (via Russia Today): The riot police appeared to respond with tear gas, and there are also reports of some other clashes between protesters and the police: The latest live TV pictures from Athens show that the scene outside the Athens parliament is still peaceful, but tense. There are clearly large numbers of riot police in attendance now: Here's a screengrab: That's from Russia Today's live feed: here. Here's a couple of good photos showing how some streets of Athens are deserted, but that riot police are in attendance: Here's a few photos showing the very large turnout for the march taking place in Athens now, organised by the PAME communist union: Elsewhere in Athens, the secondary school teachers union is marching. Here's a photo: Sounds like several thousand people are currently taking part in the rallies organised by the two major Greek unions in Athens, on top of the 15,000-25,000 who are marching with PAME now (see 10.31am). Greek police estimate that there are 15,000 people taking part in the march organised by the communist PAME group today. PAME, though, puts the figure at 25,000. (that's via twitter user @doleross ) One of the many banners at the scene reads: "We sing and we fight. Let's block the austerity measures". PAME's protest will end at Syntagma Square, and converge with other marches organised by Greek unions. Here's a photo from the PAME march, via Spyros Gkelis: Over in Athens, the loud chants of angry demonstrators are wafting over the streets, says our correspondent Helena Smith. Helena writes: Thousands of supporters of the militant communist-aligned trade union, PAME, have converged on Omonia square, their angry anti-austerity denouncements wafting over Athens. The demonstrators will march on parliament ahead of another mass gathering of protestors from the public and private sector who are currently amassing at the Pedio tou Ario park. Unions representing striking civil servants and private sector employees say perhaps more than any other protest to date, today’s is “fundamentally crucial” for the message it will send to EU leaders meeting in Brussels. Tania Karayiannis at the union of civil servants ADEDY has just told me. Decisions or moves that will lead to decisions will be taken today and it is fundamentally crucial that we send a message that policies that affect not only us but the whole of southern Europe, are just not going to pass, This pig-headed insistence on applying austerity measures that worsen recession, that kill hope or any chance of the economy rebounding, are obviously totally wrong. She said that 300,000 families were now without a single person in gainful employment as a result of the policies. It’s a huge number. In Greece I can say that desperation is growing. I think, now, we have to be more coordinated on a European level to stop these measures. It's not all good news for the Spanish this morning, though -- The Bank of Spain has reported that bad loans across its financial sector hit a new record high in August. A total of 10.5% of all loans held by Spanish banks have now fallen into arrears, up from 9.9% in July. Recent stress tests showed that Spain's banking sector needs almost €60bn of new capital, and today's data shows that the situation is not getting better. Spain has conducted a successful debt sale, in the last couple of minutes. It sold a total of €4.61bn of long-term bonds, more than its maximum target of €4.5bn. This included €1.51bn of 10-year bonds, at an average yield (or interest rate) of 5.468%, down from 5.7% at the previous auction. Spain also sold €1.46bn of four-year bonds, at an average yield of 3.977%, down from 4.603% on September. It also shifted €1.6bn of three-year debt at yields of 3.227%, down from 3.676%. It's a sign that bond traders are still prepared to buy Spanish debt, in the expectation that Madrid will soon apply for financial aid. On the corporate front AkzoNobel, the Dutch firm behind Dulux, has blamed the difficult European market for a €2.5bn writedown on its decorative paints business. The writedown has pushed it into a €2.4bn loss, my colleague Julia Kollewe reports. The company's finance chief Keith Nichols said: The principal concern remains the decorative paint markets in Europe. The impairment taken in this quarter is a reflection of these concerns and our realistic assessment of the markets going forward. As we cannot expect quick recovery of the economy, we also will continue to implement our ongoing improvement agenda in order to increase our profitability." And materials group Low & Bonar told its shareholders this morning that growth in sales of civil engineering and building products has slowed as European customers become more cautious. A further sign that Europe's dent crisis is hurting economic growth. And here's further photographic evidence that Athens is shut down for today's general strike: Crowds are gathering in Athens for today's marches organised by labour groups. This photo from twitter shows the scene at the starting point for the PAME communist union's protest: And here's the scene 80km to the west of Athens, in the capital of Corinthia: Journalist Damian Mac Con Uladh reports that traffic in Athens is very light, and that small businesses which stayed open in previous general strikes are closed today. Her also tweets a photo from the scene: The two-day EU meeting in Brussels is officially under way, with the opening of the Tripartite Social Summit (the appetizer to the red meat of the Summit this afternoon). As mentioned at 8.10am, the Social Summit is meant to address youth unemployment -- one of the most worrying economic problems which Europe is suffering from. EU president Herman Van Rompuy just tweeted that: Angela Merkel is refusing to bow to pressure from François Hollande over banking reform. Continuing her speech to the Bundestag (see 8.31am for more), chancellor Merkel said that Europe needs "quality before speed" when it comes to European banking supervision. That may infuriate fellow eurozone members who are desperate for Europe to implement banking union rapidly (as they believe was agreed at the June summit), so that weaker banks can be recapitalised. As Hollande argued out in this major interview, it is vital that Banking Union is agreed by the end of the year. The problem is that Spain and France want fresh capital to be pumped into struggling banks as soon as the European banking supervisor is up and running (ideally by the start of 2013). Germany, though, argues at the supervisor needs a proper 'track record' of success before it starts dishing out valuable capital. Greek general strikes, rather like EU summits, seem to come around with surprising frequency. According to the BBC, today's industrial action is the 20th general strike to hit Greece in the last two years. The Summit is the 4th time that EU leaders have gathered during 2012. Angela Merkel has just told German MPs that she sees signs that the eurozone is becoming more stable. Speaking to the Bundestag NOW, before shooting off to Brussels, Merkel said she could "see progress on unit labour costs" in Greece, Ireland, Portugal and Spain. On Greece, Merkel said she had seen "a strong desire for change" during her trip to Athens last week. She added that Greek prime minister Antonis Samaras will give leaders an "interim report" on negotiations with the Troika (as a final agreement has still not been reached). Merkel also reiterated that she wants Greece to remain in the eurozone. On Spain, the German chancellor said only Madrid could decide whether to ask for financial help. Once again, Syntagma Square will play host to Athenians who are protesting about the country's plight. The ADEDY and GSEE unions will hold a march starting at 11am EEST, or 9am BST, staring at Pedion tou Areos and marching to Syntagma. The communist PAME union will start its own rally shortly, at Omonia Square, and converge at Syntagma. Also, the SYRIZA opposition party is about to hold a rally outside the Archaeological Museum. Greece faces an "anti-austerity shutdown" today, according to Greek newspaper Kathimerini. It reports that Greek unions plan to bring much of the near-bankrupt country to a standstill, adding: Most business and public sector activity is expected to grind to a halt during the 24-hour strike called by the ADEDY and GSEE unions, with newspaper kiosk owners and air traffic controllers among various groups joining the protest. Ships will stay in port, Athens public transport will be disrupted and hospitals will work on emergency staff, while public offices, ministries and shops including bakeries will all be shut. As usual, Living In Greece has a comprehensive guide to the disruption. The action in Brussels will begin with a "Tripartite Social Summit" in around 30 minutes. That event is focusing on Europe's youth unemployment crisis -- details here. The actual summit won't get underway until the afternoon, with talks likely to drag on late into the evening. • Tripartite social summit: 8.30am-11.30am BST / 9.3am-12.30pm CEST • Press conference: 11.30am-12pm BST / 12.30pm-1pm CEST • Leaders arrive for the Summit: 3.15pm-3.45pm BST/4.15-4.45pm CEST • Exchange of views with the European Parliament president: 4pm-4.30pm BST / 5pm-5.30pm CEST • Family photo: 4.30pm BST / 5.30pm CEST • Working session: 4.45pm-7pm BST / 5.45pm-9pm CEST • Working dinner: 7pm-9pm BST / 8pm-10pm CEST • Press conference: TBC So, quite a long day. Other events: • Greek general strike: all day • Greek union protests: from 9am BST / 11am EEST • Spanish bond auction: from 9am BST/10am CEST Also, Angela Merkel is due to speak in the Bundestag before the Summit - any time now.... Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the eurozone financial crisis, and other key events in the global economy. It's a big day, as European leaders gather in Brussels for the eagerly awaited EU Summit. The meeting will see heated debate on issues such as banking union and eurozone budgets. Spain's possible bailout and the Greek aid package also likely to dominate the chat in the corridors of power. We're not expecting a major breakthrough (but we'd love to be disappointed). Instead, there's likely to be a major tussle between Angela Merkel and François Hollande, with the French president expected to challenge Germany's chancellor over Berlin's hard line on austerity and foot-dragging over European banking supervision. Meanwhile, over in Greece workers will be taking part in a general strike in protest at the country's financial plight. Unions will be holding demonstrations in Athens, in the latest sign of public anger over the worsening situation in Greece. We'll be tracking all the action in Brussels and Athens through the day.
